webTitle: Lloyds tightens mortgage lending rules; AstraZeneca insists Pfizer bid is final - business live

fields.standfirst:
• Closing summary
  • AstraZeneca says there's no way Pfizer bid can be increased
  • Lloyds brings in new cap on mortgages over £500,000.
  • GM recalls 2.4m cars
  • UK inflation rises to 1.8%, ahead of wages
  • Glencore criticised over all-male board
  • M&S profits fall again
fields.body:
7.18pm BST

Closing summary

That's all for tonight. A quick closing summary:

Lloyds Banking Group has responded to concerns over the London housing market by introducing a new cap on lending. It will now only lend up to four times income on loans of £500,000 or more.

Sephen Noakes, group director of mortgages, said it was a "targeted" response to the capital's housing market, where prices have risen 17% this year.

This prudent update to our lending policies is intended to manage risks to our business and for our customers.”

“The Group continues to support the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme as it has raised confidence in the housing market particularly outside of London. Help to Buy is not one of the factors driving London house prices. Just 2% of purchases in London in 2014 have been through the scheme with the significant majority of applications coming from the rest of the UK."

The move got a mixed reaction - with mortgage broker Charcol questioning if it would work.

AstraZeneca has insisted tonight that Pfizer's £55 per share offer, rejected yesterday, cannot be raised under any circumstances.

GM is recalling another 2.4m cars to fix a series of safety problems. The latest recalls cover problems with seat belts, airbags and automatic transmission systems.

The UK inflation rate has risen to 1.8% for April, up from 1.6% in March, meaning prices are increasing faster than wages.

The news has reignited concerns that Britain is still gripped by a cost of living crisis.

Here's what economists are saying about inflation

Business secretary Vince Cable has criticised Glencore after the mining group said it could take until the end of the year to hire its first female director.

Marks & Spencer has reported its third consecutive fall in annual profits, putting more pressure on CEO Marc Bolland.

Vodafone has seen its shares slide 5.5% after warning that profits will be hit by the cost of improving its network. It looks like the worst day's trading in years.

HSBC, JPMorgan and Credit Agricole have been accused of fixing derivatives linked to interest rate contracts in euros, by European Commission inspectors.

Goodnight! GW

6.55pm BST

To reiterate, AstraZeneca's statement tonight means there's no way that Pfizer's offer of £55 per share can be raised.

6.44pm BST

AstraZeneca: Pfizer bid "absolutely" cannot be raised

Some late news - AstraZeneca has just insisted that there is no chance that Pfizer could raise its £69bn takeover offer, which was rebuffed yesterday morning.

The UK drugs company has issued a statement to the City tonight to "clarify" the situation with Pfizer.

It rebuffs the idea that Pfizer's "final" £55 per share offer could somehow be improved (as some shareholders hope).

AstraZeneca is adamant that Pfizer cannot raise its bid again.

Here's the full statement: CLARIFICATION REGARDING PFIZER STATEMENT

In it Leif Johansson, chairman of AstraZeneca , blamed Pfizer for the situation:

"We have decided that it is necessary to issue a statement to make absolutely clear that Pfizer's final proposal, which the Board rejected, is not capable under the Takeover Panel rules of being increased or even suggested at being increased, privately or publicly, with or without the Board's approval or recommendation.

This restriction that prevents further negotiation on value is a consequence of Pfizer's actions.

The Board has made clear in its statement of 19 May 2014 that it is not in the interests of AstraZeneca shareholders to recommend an offer unless the value of the company and its protected delivery to shareholders is properly represented by the amount and terms of the offer."

The BBC's business editor, Kamal Ahmed, reckons this means the deal is definitely over.


Updated at 6.58pm BST

6.27pm BST

Dharshini David of Sky News points out that the new mortgage affordability tests are already restricting lending, even before Lloyds income cap comes into play.

6.12pm BST

PA: Lloyds loan-to-income cap to tackle London housing inflation

Here's the Press Association's take on Lloyds' new tougher mortgage rules (announced at 5pm tonight):

LLOYDS SETS UP LOAN-TO-INCOME CAP

Britain's biggest mortgage lender is imposing a new loan-to-income cap on people looking to borrow more than half a million pounds in a bid to tackle the pressure of housing inflation in the London market.

Lloyds Banking Group said that from today, people applying to take out a mortgage worth more than £500,000 will see the amount they are allowed to borrow limited to four times their income.

The new policy will apply across the UK but Lloyds said it is primarily designed to address specific inflationary pressures in the London market.

The policy will take place in addition to Lloyds' usual affordability checks and it will apply to mortgage lending through the group's brands of Halifax, Lloyds Bank, Bank of Scotland and Scottish Widows Bank.

The group expects the change to impact around 8% of its lending in London and around 2.5% of lending across the country.

It is understood there have been concerns that some people who are wanting to snap up high-value properties are also looking to borrow high amounts in relation to their income.

Stephen Noakes, group director of mortgages said:

"Whilst the housing market outside of London is starting to improve, the recovery is fragile and prices largely remain below their peak. It is important we don't disrupt this recovery.

"But in London, house prices are almost now 30% above the 2007 peak. This is largely driven by issues of supply which are particularly acute in London and this is having an impact on income multiples which are failing to keep pace with asset growth.

"We're not seeing such issues across the rest of the UK and therefore this is a targeted response to an issue largely in the upper tiers of the London housing market. This prudent update to our lending policies is intended to manage risks to our business and for our customers."

The announcement came as Office for National Statistics (ONS) figures showed that in London, property values have leapt more than twice as fast as the national average over the last year, with a 17.0% annual lift in the capital pushing average prices there to £459,000.

Prime Minister David Cameron also said today he would consider making changes to the Government's flagship Help to Buy mortgage scheme, if the Bank of England suggests that they are needed.

The London market continues to be a strong pull for wealthy cash buyers from overseas who are looking for good returns for their money.

Mr Noakes continued:

"The group continues to support the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme as it has raised confidence in the housing market particularly outside of London.

"Help to Buy is not one of the factors driving London house prices. Just 2% of purchases in London in 2014 have been through the scheme, with the significant majority of applications coming from the rest of the UK."

Toughened industry-wide mortgage lending rules came into force last month, which mean that lenders now have to probe mortgage applicants more deeply about their spending habits to check they can afford their mortgage repayments, both now and when interest rates eventually rise.

5.35pm BST

Ray Boulger of mortgage brokers John Charcol has questioned the logic behind Lloyds decision to limit mortgages over £500,000 to a maximum of four times income.

Boulger argued that those borrowing the largest amounts could typically afford to take the largest income multiples, as they have proportionately more disposable cash to make repayments.

Boulger said:

"From a lending point of view restricting income multiples on larger loans doesn't make sense.

"Either Lloyds thinks the London property market is a bit toppy and it is taking on too much risk with these large mortgages, or it is doing the job of the Bank of England and the government and deciding that from an economic view they are not good for the country."

Boulger said the key would be whether other lenders followed suit - otherwise the 8% of loans affected by Lloyds' move would simply end up with another lender.

(via Hilary Osborne)

5.27pm BST

Will other banks follow Lloyds' lead, wonders Bloomberg's Europe economy editor, Fergal O'Brien.

Updated at 5.27pm BST

5.21pm BST

Lloyds tightens lending policy - instant reaction

Lloyds' clampdown on high-end mortgages come just a few weeks after new affordability tests were brought in, designed to prevent reckless lending.

So where does tonight's clampdown on high mortgages leave the Mortgage Market Review, asks my colleague Hilary Osborne:

While the FT's James Mackintosh is concerned that Lloyds appears to be trying to affect the London housing market. Is that its job, he wonders?

Here's more reaction:

5.00pm BST

Lloyds tightens mortgage approval rules to address London price boom

BIG NEWS IN THE UK HOUSING MARKET:

Lloyds Banking Group has announced that it is tightening the rules surrounding mortgages on high value properties, to address "inflationary pressures" in London housing market.

The new rules means mortgage applications will be limited to a maximum of four times income on lending over £500,000. They cover any mortgages issued by Halifax, Lloyds Bank, Bank of Scotland and Scottish Widows Bank.

Lloyds says it is acting because London house prices are now 30% higher than their pre-crisis peak -- primarily due to a lack of supply.

Here is the full statement, just released:

LLOYDS BANKING GROUP ANNOUNCES TARGETED POLICY CHANGES TO ADDRESS INFLATIONARY PRESSURES IN LONDON HOUSING MARKET

Lloyds Banking Group today announces an update to its policy for new high value mortgage lending.

From today, where the mortgage lending on a property in the UK is over £500,000, the Group will assess the mortgage application by applying an income multiple limit of four. This is a targeted policy change primarily designed to address specific inflationary pressures in the London housing market. The new policy will be applied in addition to our usual affordability assessment.

Stephen Noakes, Group Director of Mortgages said:

“Whilst the housing market outside of London is starting to improve, the recovery is fragile and prices largely remain below their peak. It is important we don’t disrupt this recovery.

“But in London, house prices are almost now 30% above the 2007 peak. This is largely driven by issues of supply which are particularly acute in London and this is having an impact on income multiples which are failing to keep pace with asset growth.”

“We’re not seeing such issues across the rest of the UK and therefore this is a targeted response to an issue largely in the upper tiers of the London housing market. This prudent update to our lending policies is intended to manage risks to our business and for our customers.”

“The Group continues to support the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme as it has raised confidence in the housing market particularly outside of London. Help to Buy is not one of the factors driving London house prices. Just 2% of purchases in London in 2014 have been through the scheme with the significant majority of applications coming from the rest of the UK.”

The Group expects this policy change to impact around 8% of our lending in London.

This policy change will take effect immediately and applies to mortgage lending through Halifax, Lloyds Bank, Bank of Scotland and Scottish Widows Bank.

Updated at 5.03pm BST

4.36pm BST

GM recalls another 2.4m cars over safety problems

General Motors safety problems have deepened, again - the US car giant has just announced that it is recalling another 2.4 million vehicles, to fix four different problems.

This time, GM is recalling cars to fix problems with seat belts, automatic transmission systems, air bags, and the 'generator fuse box'.

The recall will cost it $200m, doubling its charge for recall-related repairs this quarter to $400m.

Today's four recalls means GM has now announced 29 separate safety and non-compliance recalls in the US so far this year.

Here's the details of the latest recalls:

  • 1,339,355 Buick Enclave, Chevrolet Traverse, GMC Acadia full-size crossovers from the 2009-2014 model years and Saturn Outlooks from 2009-2010 because front safety lap belt cables can fatigue and separate over time. In a crash, a separated cable could increase the risk of injury to front seat passengers.
  • 1,075,102 of the previous generation 4-speed automatic transmission Chevrolet Malibu and from the 2004-2008 model years and Pontiac G6 from the 2005-2008 model years because of a shift cable that could wear out over time, resulting in mismatches of the gear position indicated by the shift lever.
  • 1,402 Cadillac Escalades and Escalade ESVs from the 2015 model year because an insufficiently heated plastic weld that attaches the passenger side air bag to the instrument panel assembly could result in a partial deployment of the air bag in the event of a crash.
  • 58 Chevrolet Silverado HD and GMC Sierra HD full-size pickups from the 2015 model year because retention clips attaching the generator fuse block to the vehicle body can become loose and lead to a potential fire.

GM says it is aware of "18 crashes and one injury among the 4-speed Malibu and G6 population" (related to the transmission problems).

It says there are "no fatalities associated with these recalls". Full statement here.

The recall comes just days after GM was fined $35m over the problems with its faulty ignition switch, linked to 13 deaths.

Updated at 4.44pm BST

4.18pm BST

Ivan Palacios, Moody’s analyst for Vodafone, warns that the mobile operator's credit rating could be cut if its finances don't improve.

He writes:

“Moody’s negative outlook for Vodafone reflects the weakness of the company's credit metrics for the A3 rating category, with no headroom for deviation in terms of operating performance or for further debt-financed acquisitions.

Vodafone has exhausted the financial flexibility within the A3 rating that it had created following the sale of its 45% equity stake in Verizon Wireless. The rating could be downgraded over the next 12 months if the company does not strengthen its financial profile.”

A3 is the seventh-highest notch on Moody's scale, four places above 'junk'.

While today's tumble in Vodafone's share price is bad for investors, we shouldn't forget that the billions it is spending on new infrastructure should deliver better services in future.

And the competition and regulatory pressures Vodafone is suffering in Europe means better prices for consumers.

4.02pm BST

The Vodafone selloff is picking up pace - share are now down 5.3% after it warned earnings in 2015 will be lower as it pays the cost of it major network revamp.

Joshua Raymond of City Index reckons it could be the worst day for the stock in years.

3.51pm BST

This morning's surprise rise in UK inflation, to 1.8% in April, given the pound a lift in the foreign exchange markets today.

Sterling equalled a five-and-a-half-year high against a basket of currencies, and hit a 16-month high of €1.231 against the euro (as this chart shows):

Traders are calculating that the pick-up in inflation puts more pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates.

Alex Edwards, head of the corporate desk at UKForex, said:

It fuels expectations for an early rate hike from the Bank of England, this despite the dovish tone of the Inflation Report last week.

Worth remembering, though, that there's an Easter 'blip' in the inflation data, as transport costs typically go up over the holidays.

3.41pm BST

A postscript to the protest vote against Tony Hayward in Zug today, which (we assume) is flattered by the fact that 33% of Glencore is owned by, er, Glencore employees -- my colleague Simon Goodley points out.

If you exclude these loyal souls from the ballot, 12% of voting shareholders directly opposed Hayward at today's AGM, while if you include abstentions (and exclude Glencore staff) then 18% failed to support his appointment.

2.54pm BST

It's another muted day in the stock markets, with investors struggling to find reasons to push shares higher.

Wall Street just opened, and the Dow Jones industrial average has dipped by 30 points, or 0.2%, to 16476. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq are all slightly lower.

The main European markets are also in the red.

The FTSE 100 is down 40 points at 6804, a drop of 0.6%, being dragged down by Vodafone (-4.5%).

The French CAC and German DAX are both down around 0.2%, while the Italian FTSE MIB is flat.

Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, says there's been little economic news (apart from UK inflation) to interest the City:

With a lack of macro data to scare or please, the FTSE 100 has continued to give up ground from recent highs.

2.35pm BST

Here's City editor Jill Treanor's take on Glencore's failure to end its all-male board.

2.18pm BST

Speaking of Glencore... advisory firm PIRC has echoed Vince Cable's concerns over the company's failure to add a female director to its board, and told the mining giant to hurry up.

A PIRC spokesman said Tony Hayward's goal of finding one woman director by the end of the year wasn't good enough.

"If Glencore were to appoint a single woman on the board by the end of the year, that would still leave them as the laggard of the FTSE 100. The question of diversity has gone past one representative on the board,.

Glencore should foreshadow to the market now what the 2015 targets are for board diversity, and they need to get a bit of a hurry up."

PIRC, or the Pensions Investment Research Consultants, is one of the City's leading lobby groups.

2.05pm BST

Glencore AGM: 10% of shareholders fail to back Tony Hayward

Glencore Xstrata chairman Tony Hayward has suffered a small protest vote, at the company's AGM in Zug today.

More than 10% of shareholders either voted against Tony Hayward being re-elected to the board, or withheld their vote. All the other resolutions were passed with majorities in the high 90%.

Glencore reported that investors holding over 504 million shares voted against Hayward's reappointment, while those holding 421.9 million shares withheld their vote (the traditional way of flagging up concerns without actually opposing the board)

More than 8 billion shares were case in favour of Hayward, the former CEO of BP.

So that's 94% of votes in favour of Hayward- falling to below 90% when you include the withheld votes:

Full results here.

As mentioned earlier, Glencore faced criticism today for its activities in the developing world -- as well as being blasted by Vince Cable for not moving faster to appoint a female director.

Updated at 2.11pm BST

1.45pm BST

Vodafone's shares continue to be pummelled after the mobile giant admitted this morning that profits in 2015 will be hit by the cost of improving its network.

They're currently leading the FTSE fallers, down over 4.5%.

Dario Talmesio, principal analyst of Ovum’s Service Provider & Markets, says Vodafone is succeeding in moving customers onto faster mobile devices, but struggling to make more money out of them.

Talmesio explains:

“Fortunately, video consumption is driving customer demand and upgrades from 3G phones to more advanced ones. Unfortunately, the uptake of data fails to deliver in financial terms: revenues continue to fall for VodafoneGroup, meanwhile margins have severely deteriorated.

There is a certain paradox here: Vodafone is putting most of its commercial and investment efforts in something that is not turning revenues and that is mainly because of regulation* and competitive pressure – Europe is clearly the issue that needs to be addressed."

* - such as the clampdown on roaming charges.

1.09pm BST

Sources close to Pfizer reckon there is very little chance that unhappy AstraZeneca investors will create enough noise to force the two companies to the negotiating table.

The comments came after Schroders urged Astra to resume talks this morning, as my colleague Rupert Neate reports:

A source close to Pfizer said the company would be amazed if AstraZeneca's shareholders put enough pressure on the board to force it to reconsider the £55-a-share offer before a Takeover Panel deadline on 26 May.

"They would have to make an excruciatingly loud noise," the source said.

Full story: AstraZeneca shareholder calls on board to reverse Pfizer takeover bid rejection

1.02pm BST

12.56pm BST

M&S chief Marc Bolland has confirmed that no bonuses will be paid to executives or staff this year, after it reported its third consecutive fall in annual profits today.

12.43pm BST

Vince Cable blasts Glencore over all-male board

Business Secretary Vince Cable has laid into Glencore Xstrata for its failure to appoint a single woman to its board.

In a hard-hitting statement, Cable said the mining giant had "consistently failed to act", and vowed to take up the issue with chairman Tony Hayward urgently.

Today's pledge (see last post) to appoint a female director by the end of the year simply isn't good enough, Cable says.

Responding to Hayward's promise to appoint woman by the end of 2014, Cable said:

"These changes are long overdue.

The company has had over three years to address this issue. It has been saying for over a year that they were in the process of appointing a woman to the board, and I specifically met the chief executive to discuss its performance on this issue. It has consistently failed to act.

The vast majority of Britain's top companies have got the message that a diverse top management team is good for business - it is simply not credible that one company cannot find any suitable women. I will be speaking with their incoming chairman Tony Hayward and will raise this as a matter of priority."

12.35pm BST

After sustained criticism, mining giant Glencore Xstrata has promised to appoint a woman director to its current all-male board.

However, it might take until the end of the year for Glencore Xstrata to catch up with the rest of the City -- hardly a signal that it is desperate to rectify the situation.

At its AGM today, chairman Tony Hayward said Glencore Xstrata would appoint a female director to its board by the end of 2014.

"Glencore values and promotes diversity across the company," Hayward said, as he opened Glencore's AGM.

Despite those "values", Glencore Xstrata is the only FTSE 100 company to not include a single woman on its board --three years after a landmark report called for women to occupy 25% of all board positions by 2015.

During the AGM, Glencore Xstrata was also criticised for its conduct in the developing world.

Jim Armitage of the Evening Standard reports:

A private shareholder said his son had questioned him about the morality of owning Glencore Xstrata shares in the light of the huge amount of negative publicity: “Daddy, I keep reading about this company in the news, what does it do when it goes to the developing countries it operates in?”

Hayward, whose permanent appointment to the chairmanship was announced recently, said GlencoreXstrata invests heavily where it operates: “When we invest we create many very well paid jobs, and each of those supports families of seven or eight people.”

Updated at 12.36pm BST

12.10pm BST

UK inflation: What the economists say

Back to April's inflation data, and Alan Clarke of Scotiabank agrees that living standards are still being squeezed - echoing Unite's concerns this morning.

Clarke says:

While it is encouraging that inflation is falling for goods that people ‘have to’ buy – i.e. food and energy, today’s data continue to show a squeeze on living standards.

The average worker that doesn’t get a bonus is seeing wage increases of just 1.3% y/y versus CPI price increases of 1.8% y/y. Clearly both measures are volatile, but the fact remains that household budgets continue to be squeezed.

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce, says domestic labour costs -- largely made up of wages -- are unlikely to rise strongly this year:

We expect world commodity prices to remain subdued and domestic labour costs will probably only rise slightly over the coming months.

This suggests that inflation will remain around or just below the 2% mark.

Martin Beck, senior economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club, points out that we don't actually know how wage packets fared in April, but March's payroll data does suggest real wages are falling:

“After six consecutive monthly falls, April broke inflation’s downward trend with the CPI measure rising from 1.6% to 1.8%. As a result, if headline wages growth holds steady at its March level, the squeeze on real wages will be back on.

“We do not think this rise is the precursor to a sustained uptick. The timing of the Easter break boosted various prices, such as the cost of flights compared with April 2013, while the fall in petrol prices that we saw last April didn’t reoccur this time round.

Eimear Daly, head of market analysis at Monex Europe, warns that global factors could push UK inflation higher:

The real focus was the jump in core inflation to 2%, reversing all the declines seen since September 2013.

"The divergence between core and headline price growth shows that the UK has benefitted from lower global food and energy prices and a stronger sterling in reining in inflation. These prices are set on global financial markets and can reverse declines just as quickly as they fell.

Updated at 12.47pm BST

11.39am BST

City investors remain unimpressed with Marks & Spencer, whose shares are down almost 3% after posting its third annual decline in profits (as covered in the opening posts).

CEO Marc Bolland is meeting City reporters now, and insisting that the task of transforming M&S's IT and logistics chain is "almost complete" - even if you can't see the benefits yet.

11.26am BST

EU accuses HSBC, JP Morgan and Credit Agricole over euro rate fix

Another development in the interest rate benchmark fixing scandal -- antitrust regulators in Brussels have just brought preliminary charges against HSBC, JP Morgan and Credit Agricole.

The three banks are accused of colluding to rig financial benchmarks linked to the euro.

In a statement, the EU competition authority said:

The European Commission has informed Crédit Agricole, HSBC and JPMorgan of its preliminary view that they may have breached EU antitrust rules by colluding to influence the pricing of interest rate derivatives denominated in the euro currency.

HSBC, JP Morgan and Credit Agricole had all resisted settling with the EU last year over the issue.

Four other banks did admit their involvement in a cartel relating to euro interest rate derivatives, and were fined more than €1bn.

11.04am BST

Schroders urges AstraZeneca to resume talks with Pfizer

Schroders, the asset management company, has made a late bid to reignite Pfizer's pursuit of AstraZeneca by urging the UK firm to engage with its US rival.

Fund manager Sue Noffke went public with Schroders' concerns this morning, saying it was disappointed with both companies.

She wants AstraZeneca to resume talks with Pfizer over its £55 per share "final offer", before the deadline of 26 May, saying:

“Schroders notes with disappointment the quick rejection by the AstraZeneca Board of the latest offer from Pfizer and the decision of the Pfizer Board to draw a premature end to these negotiations by calling their latest proposal Final.

As long term shareholders, we are strong believers in AstraZeneca and the potential for its innovative growth pipeline, however, given the increase in the offer we would encourage the AstraZeneca management to recommence their engagement with Pfizer, and subsequently their shareholders.”

AstraZeneca shares are still down this morning, though, having lost around 1% to £42.48.

Updated at 11.07am BST

10.58am BST

10.51am BST

Unite chief Len McCluskey is also disappointed that real wages are lagging inflation again -- it's proof that the cost of living crisis continues, he says.

McCluskey added:

"People are living on a knife edge, there is no room for manoeuvre in family budgets and if interest rates rise they will be tipped over the edge.

Cameron and Osborne have shown they are blind to the everyday struggles of people trying to make ends meet. We need an economy that works for ordinary working people, a boost to the minimum wage of £1.50 an hour and end to the pernicious rise of the insecurity of zero hours contracts.”

(correction, McCluskey runs Unite, of course, not the TUC as I initially wrote.)

Updated at 12.57pm BST

10.42am BST

The Labour party have accused the government of complacency, after today's inflation figures showed prices rising faster than wages.

Here's Catherine McKinnell MP, Shadow Treasury Minister:

“These figures underline why this Tory-led government is wrong to be so complacent about the cost-of-living crisis.

“Wages after inflation have fallen by an average of £1,600 a year since 2010 and the link between the wealth of the nation and family finances is broken. A huge turnaround is needed to ensure working people aren’t worse off than when David Cameron came to office.

“While the Tories try to deny it even exists, Labour has a clear plan to deal with the cost-of-living crisis and earn our way to higher living standards for all, not just a few at the top."

10.33am BST

The government has welcomed the fact that the UK inflation rate is below the 2% target.

Here's the official line from the Treasury:

“The latest figures show that inflation remains below the target rate and well below half of the peak in September 2011. Lower inflation and rising job numbers show that the government’s long term plan is working and Britain is coming back.

The biggest risk to economic security would be abandoning the plan that is creating a brighter economic future."

10.26am BST

Rob Wood of Berenberg bank has found reasons to be optimistic about the latest inflation data:

There was good news on the price of essentials, which has been heavily squeezing households. Petrol prices were still down 5.0% year-on-year.

Food price inflation slipped to +0.5% year-on-year. Utilities price increases eased to 4.8% yoy.

Indeed, on a monthly basis, food prices actually fell by 0.5% in April compared to March.

Wood also points out that the late arrival of Easter (unlike in 2013 when it was early) has made the inflation data harder to interpret.

We will not get a clean read on inflation until the May figures. An average of the past two months is a reasonable way of filtering out the Easter noise, which puts core inflation at 1.8% and headline inflation at 1.7%, close to the BoE’s target.

10.16am BST

Having fallen again last month, real wages are unlikely to grow significantly for many months, warns Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight.

Archer reckons inflation will remain below the Bank of England's 2% targetfor the rest of 2014, but fears that many employers will still be reluctant to raise wages substantially.

He says:

We doubt that earnings growth will race ahead. Companies are still keen to contain their costs in an ongoing competitive environment while still appreciable labour market slack limits workers’ ability to push for higher pay.

Limited productivity growth may also limit wage growth.

10.02am BST

So, despite the strong-looking economic recovery in recent months, inflation is still rising faster than wages.

Jeremy Cook, chief economist of World First, warns that wages growth won't pick up until the spare capacity in the labour market has been absorbed:

“Inflation remains below target as it stands at the moment, but April’s increase has seen inflation back to outstripping wages. Mark Carney, said at the weekend that the Bank of England hopes that wages will accelerate soon, as productivity increases, and we will see a near-term lull in inflation.

“Labour market slack still exists and we will not see wages increase meaningfully until the labour market tightens further.

Updated at 10.04am BST

9.56am BST

This chart shows how real wages are still falling in the UK.

It subtracts average wage growth excluding bonuses from the CPI inflation rate -- if the result is negative (below the blue line), then incomes are failing to keep pace with rising prices.

(via Jamie McGeever of Reuters.)

Updated at 10.17am BST

9.49am BST

Back to inflation, and this chart confirms how transport prices rose faster than other costs last month - driving the Consumer Prices Index up to 1.8%.

Updated at 9.49am BST

9.44am BST

...but UK house price growth slows

In a flurry of data, the ONS also reported that UK house prices rose by 8.0% year-on-year in March; a rapid pace, but actually slower than February's reading of 9.2%.

London house prices have surged by 17% in the last year, it added.

9.41am BST

9.40am BST

April's jump in CPI inflation was partly due to rising transport costs, with airlines putting up prices to coincide with the Easter rush.

Food price inflation eased, though, according to the Office for National Statistics:

  • Increases in transport costs, notably air fares, sea fares and motor fuels, provided the largest contribution to the rise in the rate. An overall fall in the price of food was the largest offsetting factor.
  • The timing of Easter is likely to have had an impact on the index – most notably for air fares and sea fares.

9.39am BST

The Retail Prices Index, the wider measure of inflation, was unchanged at 2.5%.

9.33am BST

UK inflation rate rises to 1.8%

The UK inflation rate has risen to 1.8% in the 12 months to April, up from 1.6% in March.

That means prices are rising faster than wage growth -- as average earnings rose by 1.7% in the three months to February, and by only 1.4% if bonuses are stripped out.

Detail and reaction to follow...

9.21am BST

Coming up next (at 9.30am), new inflation data that will show if Britain's cost of living squeeze improved, or got worse, last month.

Economists predict that the Consumer Prices Index inched up to 1.7% in the 12 months to April, from 1.6% in March. If so, that would mean prices are rising in line with earnings (which grew at 1.7% in the three months to February, according to last week's data).

If CPI rises to 1.8%, as some economists suspect, that would mean real wages are falling again...

Updated at 9.26am BST

9.11am BST

Britain's booming house market appears to have boosted flooring firm Topps Tiles which posted an 11.7% jump in sales in the last six months.

Pre-tax earnings leapt from £4.7m to £8m, suggesting it is profiting as consumer confidence improves and more people move house.

9.04am BST

David Cameron: We'd listen if Bank of England warned over Help to Buy

David Cameron has said the government would listen if the Bank of England urged changes to the "Help to Buy" mortgage subsidy scheme.

After being pressed about Britain's buoyant housing market, the prime minister said it was "absolutely right" that the government is alert to dangers in the sector.

When asked if the government would consider changing the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme to reduce its upper borrowing limit [currently £600,000], Cameron said:

"Of course. We will consider any changes that are proposed by Mark Carney."

On Sunday, governor Mark Carney said the housing market was the 'biggest threat' to the UK economy, having seen prices rise over 10% in the last year.

Updated at 9.05am BST

8.55am BST

Marc Bolland can insisting that he's doing the right things, and enjoying his job, but the reality is that M&S has missed the sales target he set back in 2010.

As our story on M&S's results explains:

Bolland, who joined from Morrisons four years ago, has been under pressure from shareholder concerns that the billions of pounds he was spending were not paying off. Two years ago Bolland set out a revised plan to increase group sales from £9.7bn in 2011 to between £10.8bn and £11.4bn.

M&S today reported group sales of £10.3bn for last year.

His original plan, set out in 2010, was even more ambitious with a top-end target of £12.5bn although that was scaled back in 2012 with Bolland citing tough market conditions.

M&S profits dip for third year as retailer fails to reach sales target

8.31am BST

MS& conference call - the highlights

Here are the highlights from Marks & Spencer's conference call with City hacks, via my colleague Sean Farrell:

And as flagged up at 8.20am, M&S's CFO also denied that its website was having problems, despite needing a four to six-month settling in period.

Updated at 8.49am BST

8.31am BST

M&S's financial results haven't impressed analyst Freddie George of Cantor, who is sticking with his recommendation to sell M&S shares,

George reckons M&S is a long way from cracking its womenswear offering (as the photo at 7.56am rather indicates):

We continue to believe it will take a number of seasons before the existing team is able to manifest a marked improvement in performance in womenswear.

There has, we believe, been an improvement in the showcase autumn/winter ranges but the branding and the demographic and age profile of its target customer remains unclear.

George also fears that M&S's efforts to improve its creaking IT and supply chain won't actually boost profits.

8.24am BST

AstraZeneca shares have also fallen this morning, down another 2.2% to £41.95.

Overnight, Pfizer clarified that there is no way it can raise its 'final' offer of £55 per share without a recommendation from Astra, dampening any remaining hopes that the deal could be revived.

8.20am BST

M&S is speaking to City reporters now, and denying that its website is suffering a dose of the gremlins:

  • MARKS & SPENCER CFO SAYS "NOTHING WRONG WITH NEW WEBSITE", NOT EXPERIENCING LOGISTICAL PROBLEMS

8.16am BST

Vodafone shares are leading the fallers in London, dropping 3% in early trading.

It warned this morning that profits will be lower than forecast in 2015, partly due to the cost of improving its infrastructure (dubbed Project Spring)

But it also wiped £6.6bn off the value of its European networks, blaming fierce competition, a tough economic climate, and regulatory changes. Vodafone warned that:

We experienced revenue declines in all of our major European markets, and related pressure on margins, despite continuing measures to control costs.

8.05am BST

Marks & Spencer shares have dropped 1.5% in early trading in London to 444.6p, as investors react to this morning's financial results (online here), and the warning that creating the new M&S web site needs a six-month 'settling in' period.

Updated at 8.08am BST

8.03am BST

8.02am BST

Marc Bolland has defended his track record at M&S, which he joined four years ago this month, telling Radio 4's Today Programme that "I really enjoy my role."

Press Association has the details:

He pointed to the "heavy lifting" that had needed to be done with investments in IT and logistics which "the company didn't do for the last 15 to 20 years".

"So, over the last three years, we've done lots of investments that have made the company at the moment fit for purpose. Over the next three years there is more delivery to come and we'll certainly concentrate on that."

7.56am BST

M&S insists that it is improving its clothing range, creating more "quality and style", after suffering a -1.4% drop in general merchandise sales last year.

It told investors:

Over the course of last year, we upgraded 70% of our fabrics, added more luxurious finishes and improved our 'better and best' offer with more leather, silk and cashmere. We delivered more clarity and distinction to our sub-brands to make them more compelling and easier to shop.

We launched M&S Collection, and by streamlining the brands reduced product overlap by 10%.

But has M&S cracked it? ITN business editor Jess Brammar isn't convinced:

7.50am BST

M&S profits fall for third year running

Marks & Spencer has suffered a drop in profits for the third year running, as the company struggle to bring some magic back to its clothing division.

M&S told the City that underlying pre-tax profits fell by 3.9% in the last year, to £623m. It's an unwelcome hat-trick for boss Marc Bolland, who has seen earnings drop steadily since taking over in 2010.

And a cursory look at the numbers shows that the company's food branches are propping the rest of the business up.

M&S reported that, in the 12 months to 29 March:

  • • Total UK sales +2.3%: Food +4.2%; General Merchandise (including clothing) 0.0%
  • • Like-for-like UK sales +0.2%: Food +1.7%; General Merchandise -1.4%

Bolland insists that the company is making progress with clothing sales improving in recent weeks.

We are focused on improving our performance in General Merchandise and were pleased to see early signs of improvement. Our Food business had a very strong year, consistently outperforming the market.

M&S has now "refreshed" its Womenswear departments in its top 70 stores, in a bid to boost turnover.

But M&S also cautioned that it faces some disruption as it tries to get its new web site up to speed.

Our new M&S.com site will take four to six months to settle in and, as a consequence, will have some impact on General Merchandise performance in the first quarter.

Reaction to follow....

7.34am BST

Coming up; M&S figures and UK inflation

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, business and the eurozone.

Coming up today..... new UK inflation figures will show whether the income squeeze in Britain eased or tightened last month.

The Office for National Statistics releases its data at 9.30am - and economists fear that consumer prices index may have inched back up again, to 1.7%. That would put it in line with earnings growth in the last quarter -- meaning real wages would have stalled.

In the City, two heavyweight companies - Marks & Spencer and Vodafone - are reporting their full-year results.

We'll be watching the fallout after AstraZeneca rejected Pfizer's £69bn takeover bid yesterday morning. Many investors still aren't happy, but the battle appears to be over...

And in Europe, there's still tension ahead of this week's elections to the European Parliament, with analysts wondering just how badly the established parties will do; and what impact that has on the eurozone...

I'll be tracking the key events through the day
fields.bodyText: That's all for tonight. A quick closing summary: Lloyds Banking Group has responded to concerns over the London housing market by introducing a new cap on lending. It will now only lend up to four times income on loans of £500,000 or more. Sephen Noakes, group director of mortgages, said it was a "targeted" response to the capital's housing market, where prices have risen 17% this year. This prudent update to our lending policies is intended to manage risks to our business and for our customers.” “The Group continues to support the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme as it has raised confidence in the housing market particularly outside of London. Help to Buy is not one of the factors driving London house prices. Just 2% of purchases in London in 2014 have been through the scheme with the significant majority of applications coming from the rest of the UK." The move got a mixed reaction - with mortgage broker Charcol questioning if it would work. AstraZeneca has insisted tonight that Pfizer's £55 per share offer, rejected yesterday, cannot be raised under any circumstances. GM is recalling another 2.4m cars to fix a series of safety problems. The latest recalls cover problems with seat belts, airbags and automatic transmission systems. The UK inflation rate has risen to 1.8% for April, up from 1.6% in March, meaning prices are increasing faster than wages. The news has reignited concerns that Britain is still gripped by a cost of living crisis. Here's what economists are saying about inflation Business secretary Vince Cable has criticised Glencore after the mining group said it could take until the end of the year to hire its first female director. Marks & Spencer has reported its third consecutive fall in annual profits, putting more pressure on CEO Marc Bolland. Vodafone has seen its shares slide 5.5% after warning that profits will be hit by the cost of improving its network. It looks like the worst day's trading in years. HSBC, JPMorgan and Credit Agricole have been accused of fixing derivatives linked to interest rate contracts in euros, by European Commission inspectors. Goodnight! GW To reiterate, AstraZeneca's statement tonight means there's no way that Pfizer's offer of £55 per share can be raised. Some late news - AstraZeneca has just insisted that there is no chance that Pfizer could raise its £69bn takeover offer, which was rebuffed yesterday morning. The UK drugs company has issued a statement to the City tonight to "clarify" the situation with Pfizer. It rebuffs the idea that Pfizer's "final" £55 per share offer could somehow be improved (as some shareholders hope). AstraZeneca is adamant that Pfizer cannot raise its bid again. Here's the full statement: CLARIFICATION REGARDING PFIZER STATEMENT In it Leif Johansson, chairman of AstraZeneca , blamed Pfizer for the situation: "We have decided that it is necessary to issue a statement to make absolutely clear that Pfizer's final proposal, which the Board rejected, is not capable under the Takeover Panel rules of being increased or even suggested at being increased, privately or publicly, with or without the Board's approval or recommendation. This restriction that prevents further negotiation on value is a consequence of Pfizer's actions. The Board has made clear in its statement of 19 May 2014 that it is not in the interests of AstraZeneca shareholders to recommend an offer unless the value of the company and its protected delivery to shareholders is properly represented by the amount and terms of the offer." The BBC's business editor, Kamal Ahmed, reckons this means the deal is definitely over. Dharshini David of Sky News points out that the new mortgage affordability tests are already restricting lending, even before Lloyds income cap comes into play. Here's the Press Association's take on Lloyds' new tougher mortgage rules (announced at 5pm tonight): LLOYDS SETS UP LOAN-TO-INCOME CAP Britain's biggest mortgage lender is imposing a new loan-to-income cap on people looking to borrow more than half a million pounds in a bid to tackle the pressure of housing inflation in the London market. Lloyds Banking Group said that from today, people applying to take out a mortgage worth more than £500,000 will see the amount they are allowed to borrow limited to four times their income. The new policy will apply across the UK but Lloyds said it is primarily designed to address specific inflationary pressures in the London market. The policy will take place in addition to Lloyds' usual affordability checks and it will apply to mortgage lending through the group's brands of Halifax, Lloyds Bank, Bank of Scotland and Scottish Widows Bank. The group expects the change to impact around 8% of its lending in London and around 2.5% of lending across the country. It is understood there have been concerns that some people who are wanting to snap up high-value properties are also looking to borrow high amounts in relation to their income. Stephen Noakes, group director of mortgages said: "Whilst the housing market outside of London is starting to improve, the recovery is fragile and prices largely remain below their peak. It is important we don't disrupt this recovery. "But in London, house prices are almost now 30% above the 2007 peak. This is largely driven by issues of supply which are particularly acute in London and this is having an impact on income multiples which are failing to keep pace with asset growth. "We're not seeing such issues across the rest of the UK and therefore this is a targeted response to an issue largely in the upper tiers of the London housing market. This prudent update to our lending policies is intended to manage risks to our business and for our customers." The announcement came as Office for National Statistics (ONS) figures showed that in London, property values have leapt more than twice as fast as the national average over the last year, with a 17.0% annual lift in the capital pushing average prices there to £459,000. Prime Minister David Cameron also said today he would consider making changes to the Government's flagship Help to Buy mortgage scheme, if the Bank of England suggests that they are needed. The London market continues to be a strong pull for wealthy cash buyers from overseas who are looking for good returns for their money. Mr Noakes continued: "The group continues to support the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme as it has raised confidence in the housing market particularly outside of London. "Help to Buy is not one of the factors driving London house prices. Just 2% of purchases in London in 2014 have been through the scheme, with the significant majority of applications coming from the rest of the UK." Toughened industry-wide mortgage lending rules came into force last month, which mean that lenders now have to probe mortgage applicants more deeply about their spending habits to check they can afford their mortgage repayments, both now and when interest rates eventually rise. Ray Boulger of mortgage brokers John Charcol has questioned the logic behind Lloyds decision to limit mortgages over £500,000 to a maximum of four times income. Boulger argued that those borrowing the largest amounts could typically afford to take the largest income multiples, as they have proportionately more disposable cash to make repayments. Boulger said: "From a lending point of view restricting income multiples on larger loans doesn't make sense. "Either Lloyds thinks the London property market is a bit toppy and it is taking on too much risk with these large mortgages, or it is doing the job of the Bank of England and the government and deciding that from an economic view they are not good for the country." Boulger said the key would be whether other lenders followed suit - otherwise the 8% of loans affected by Lloyds' move would simply end up with another lender. (via Hilary Osborne) Will other banks follow Lloyds' lead, wonders Bloomberg's Europe economy editor, Fergal O'Brien. Lloyds' clampdown on high-end mortgages come just a few weeks after new affordability tests were brought in, designed to prevent reckless lending. So where does tonight's clampdown on high mortgages leave the Mortgage Market Review, asks my colleague Hilary Osborne: While the FT's James Mackintosh is concerned that Lloyds appears to be trying to affect the London housing market. Is that its job, he wonders? Here's more reaction: BIG NEWS IN THE UK HOUSING MARKET: Lloyds Banking Group has announced that it is tightening the rules surrounding mortgages on high value properties, to address "inflationary pressures" in London housing market. The new rules means mortgage applications will be limited to a maximum of four times income on lending over £500,000. They cover any mortgages issued by Halifax, Lloyds Bank, Bank of Scotland and Scottish Widows Bank. Lloyds says it is acting because London house prices are now 30% higher than their pre-crisis peak -- primarily due to a lack of supply. Here is the full statement, just released: LLOYDS BANKING GROUP ANNOUNCES TARGETED POLICY CHANGES TO ADDRESS INFLATIONARY PRESSURES IN LONDON HOUSING MARKET Lloyds Banking Group today announces an update to its policy for new high value mortgage lending. From today, where the mortgage lending on a property in the UK is over £500,000, the Group will assess the mortgage application by applying an income multiple limit of four. This is a targeted policy change primarily designed to address specific inflationary pressures in the London housing market. The new policy will be applied in addition to our usual affordability assessment. Stephen Noakes, Group Director of Mortgages said: “Whilst the housing market outside of London is starting to improve, the recovery is fragile and prices largely remain below their peak. It is important we don’t disrupt this recovery. “But in London, house prices are almost now 30% above the 2007 peak. This is largely driven by issues of supply which are particularly acute in London and this is having an impact on income multiples which are failing to keep pace with asset growth.” “We’re not seeing such issues across the rest of the UK and therefore this is a targeted response to an issue largely in the upper tiers of the London housing market. This prudent update to our lending policies is intended to manage risks to our business and for our customers.” “The Group continues to support the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme as it has raised confidence in the housing market particularly outside of London. Help to Buy is not one of the factors driving London house prices. Just 2% of purchases in London in 2014 have been through the scheme with the significant majority of applications coming from the rest of the UK.” The Group expects this policy change to impact around 8% of our lending in London. This policy change will take effect immediately and applies to mortgage lending through Halifax, Lloyds Bank, Bank of Scotland and Scottish Widows Bank. General Motors safety problems have deepened, again - the US car giant has just announced that it is recalling another 2.4 million vehicles, to fix four different problems. This time, GM is recalling cars to fix problems with seat belts, automatic transmission systems, air bags, and the 'generator fuse box'. The recall will cost it $200m, doubling its charge for recall-related repairs this quarter to $400m. Today's four recalls means GM has now announced 29 separate safety and non-compliance recalls in the US so far this year. Here's the details of the latest recalls: 1,339,355 Buick Enclave, Chevrolet Traverse, GMC Acadia full-size crossovers from the 2009-2014 model years and Saturn Outlooks from 2009-2010 because front safety lap belt cables can fatigue and separate over time. In a crash, a separated cable could increase the risk of injury to front seat passengers. 1,075,102 of the previous generation 4-speed automatic transmission Chevrolet Malibu and from the 2004-2008 model years and Pontiac G6 from the 2005-2008 model years because of a shift cable that could wear out over time, resulting in mismatches of the gear position indicated by the shift lever. 1,402 Cadillac Escalades and Escalade ESVs from the 2015 model year because an insufficiently heated plastic weld that attaches the passenger side air bag to the instrument panel assembly could result in a partial deployment of the air bag in the event of a crash. 58 Chevrolet Silverado HD and GMC Sierra HD full-size pickups from the 2015 model year because retention clips attaching the generator fuse block to the vehicle body can become loose and lead to a potential fire. GM says it is aware of "18 crashes and one injury among the 4-speed Malibu and G6 population" (related to the transmission problems). It says there are "no fatalities associated with these recalls". Full statement here. The recall comes just days after GM was fined $35m over the problems with its faulty ignition switch, linked to 13 deaths. Ivan Palacios, Moody’s analyst for Vodafone, warns that the mobile operator's credit rating could be cut if its finances don't improve. He writes: “Moody’s negative outlook for Vodafone reflects the weakness of the company's credit metrics for the A3 rating category, with no headroom for deviation in terms of operating performance or for further debt-financed acquisitions. Vodafone has exhausted the financial flexibility within the A3 rating that it had created following the sale of its 45% equity stake in Verizon Wireless. The rating could be downgraded over the next 12 months if the company does not strengthen its financial profile.” A3 is the seventh-highest notch on Moody's scale, four places above 'junk'. While today's tumble in Vodafone's share price is bad for investors, we shouldn't forget that the billions it is spending on new infrastructure should deliver better services in future. And the competition and regulatory pressures Vodafone is suffering in Europe means better prices for consumers. The Vodafone selloff is picking up pace - share are now down 5.3% after it warned earnings in 2015 will be lower as it pays the cost of it major network revamp. Joshua Raymond of City Index reckons it could be the worst day for the stock in years. This morning's surprise rise in UK inflation, to 1.8% in April, given the pound a lift in the foreign exchange markets today. Sterling equalled a five-and-a-half-year high against a basket of currencies, and hit a 16-month high of €1.231 against the euro (as this chart shows): Traders are calculating that the pick-up in inflation puts more pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates. Alex Edwards, head of the corporate desk at UKForex, said: It fuels expectations for an early rate hike from the Bank of England, this despite the dovish tone of the Inflation Report last week. Worth remembering, though, that there's an Easter 'blip' in the inflation data, as transport costs typically go up over the holidays. A postscript to the protest vote against Tony Hayward in Zug today, which (we assume) is flattered by the fact that 33% of Glencore is owned by, er, Glencore employees -- my colleague Simon Goodley points out. If you exclude these loyal souls from the ballot, 12% of voting shareholders directly opposed Hayward at today's AGM, while if you include abstentions (and exclude Glencore staff) then 18% failed to support his appointment. It's another muted day in the stock markets, with investors struggling to find reasons to push shares higher. Wall Street just opened, and the Dow Jones industrial average has dipped by 30 points, or 0.2%, to 16476. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq are all slightly lower. The main European markets are also in the red. The FTSE 100 is down 40 points at 6804, a drop of 0.6%, being dragged down by Vodafone (-4.5%). The French CAC and German DAX are both down around 0.2%, while the Italian FTSE MIB is flat. Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, says there's been little economic news (apart from UK inflation) to interest the City: With a lack of macro data to scare or please, the FTSE 100 has continued to give up ground from recent highs. Here's City editor Jill Treanor's take on Glencore's failure to end its all-male board. But has M&S cracked it? M&S told the City that underlying pre-tax profits fell by 3.9% in the last year, to £623m. webTitle: What do 'disappointed' investors really want from Pfizer and AstraZeneca?

fields.bodyText: What do these "disappointed" fund managers calling for more "engagement" between AstraZeneca and Pfizer actually want? If Schroders, the latest to join the chorus, stated out loud that AstraZeneca's board was silly to reject £55-a-share one would understand. It would be expressing a clear and straightforward opinion. But that's not what Schroders is saying. It merely thinks Pfizer drew a "premature end" to negotiations by declaring £55 to be a final proposal and it wants to "encourage the AstraZeneca management to recommence their engagement with Pfizer." But there was plenty of engagement with Pfizer – that's what the talks at the weekend were all about. For better or worse, no deal was possible. AstraZeneca wanted at least £58.85 and Pfizer wouldn't go that high. But, comes the reply, the price gap is only 7% and there is other stuff to talk about, like how a combined company would operate. And maybe a technical interpretation of the Takeover Panel's ruling on what constitutes a "final" offer has left the door ajar. Forget it. AstraZeneca's board took a view on what the company was worth and stuck to it. That is a role directors are appointed to perform. Equally, Pfizer's board set out what it was willing to pay, honouring its commitment to its own shareholders to be "disciplined" on price. If the two figures don't meet, there's no deal – and thus no need to discuss other material issues like the solidity of Pfizer's tax inversion plan and how to ringfence AstraZeneca research projects. For a clear statement on how the land lies, listen to Fidelity's Dominic Rossi, who happens to thinks AstraZeneca did the right thing. "The Astra board has taken a very difficult decision. They understood in rejecting the offer they would be criticised by some shareholders. We will now have to wait two to three years to see whether they were right. With a little luck they could well be." Yes, that's a clear assessment.

webTitle: TalkTalk, the 'ageing Ford Cortina', is motoring along, chief executive says

fields.standfirst: TalkTalk's Dido Harding has ambitious plans for the internet provider – and for children's safety online
fields.body:
As Dido Harding perches on the edge of a large sofa, casting her mind back over the four years since she became chief executive of the broadband provider TalkTalk, the smell of popcorn wafts up from the lobby below her office.

Staff are celebrating after the upstart rival to Sky, BT and Virgin Media just signed its 1 millionth TV customer. Harding says there were times when it seemed this moment would never come.

"My mental analogy for TalkTalk," she confides, "is an ageing Ford Cortina going flat out in the fast lane of the M4 in the pouring rain. We are always hammering along faster than anybody thinks is sensible, with things not quite working, but huge enthusiasm."

Even before its 2010 de-merger from Carphone Warehouse, TalkTalk spent its early years swerving from one crisis to another – such as its 2006 offer of free internet which left the company swamped, and then a merger with Tiscali which left customers billed for services they had never received.

Harding set about retuning the TalkTalk engine, but the process was sometimes painful. "I've stood in front of 500 extremely angry people in Waterford when we closed a call centre there. That's not fun, and the day you think it is fun is the day you shouldn't be doing it."

The reward came last week, when TalkTalk declared it had added more TV customers over the past year than all of its larger rivals put together. Admittedly only 28% of them watch paid content, but everyone spends at least £8.50 a month for the service.

Along the road, Harding has found time for two other projects, both of which could have bigger repercussions than cheap pay television.

The first culminated last week with the founding of Internet Matters, a website backed by all four of the big internet providers designed to help parents keep their children safe online.

Harding has made the issue of child internet safety something of a personal crusade. Before she joined TalkTalk the company had been developing Homesafe, an optional filter to screen out unsavoury content, but she made sure it saw the light of day. As a mother of two girls, now aged seven and eight, she felt the need to act.

"These can so easily become polarised issues of moral philosophy, from the free internet rights brigade at one end of the spectrum to the Mary Whitehouse anti-porn brigade at the other, and then no one agrees with anyone on anything and nothing happens. Launching Homesafe made it seem possible in everybody's minds."

As a member of the UK Council for Child Internet Safety, she campaigned for the rest of the industry to follow suit. Soon, politicians joined in. At a cyber summit last November, David Cameron urged BT, Sky and Virgin to install filters. By the end of this year, every one of their customers will have a block switched on unless they explicitly opt out.

"Internet safety is quite like the road safety issues when I was growing up as a child. You had clunk click advertising and the green cross man coming into schools to talk to children."

Harding wants a green cross code for the digital superhighway, including online safety lessons built into the national curriculum in primary schools.

Born the Honourable Diana Harding, she is an unlikely technology boss. The granddaughter of field marshall John Harding, who commanded the desert rats in the second world war, she graduated from Oxford and rebelled against an upbringing where she wasn't really expected to have a career. In the early years, she put her five foot two inch frame to good use by moonlighting as a jockey. At the same time, she climbed the corporate ladder, with a stint at McKinsey followed by senior roles at Tesco and then Sainsbury's.

Her husband is the Conservative MP and government whip John Penrose, and the prime minister was her contemporary at Oxford. But Harding vehemently denies she used such political connections to advance the child safety agenda.

"I promise you I try very hard to stay out of party politics. I run away from it. The right I have had to speak on the subject is because of TalkTalk, not because of anything to do with what my husband does."

Harding's second big project is just beginning. Until now, TalkTalk has relied on BT's network to get broadband to its customers. That could be about to change. A pilot joint venture in York will see the firm team up with Sky and fibre-optic specialist CityFibre to connect 200,000 homes. This network will be funded by loans from infrastructure investors, with the future revenue from Sky and TalkTalk customers as collateral.

If the project is a success, Harding wants to target all cities with populations between 50,000 and 100,000. Many say this is a threat designed to force BT to lower its charges . "It is not about TalkTalk investing hundreds of millions in digging up roads. We bring customers. That is what enables it to be funded through debt. That's why the share price hasn't tanked, plus the fact that we are, as a company, serially underestimated."

Harding set about retuning the TalkTalk engine, but the process was sometimes painful. "I've stood in front of 500 extremely angry people in Waterford when we closed a call centre there. That's not fun, and the day you think it is fun is the day you shouldn't be doing it." The reward came last week, when TalkTalk declared it had added more TV customers over the past year than all of its larger rivals put together. Admittedly only 28% of them watch paid content, but everyone spends at least £8.50 a month for the service. Along the road, Harding has found time for two other projects, both of which could have bigger repercussions than cheap pay television. The first culminated last week with the founding of Internet Matters, a website backed by all four of the big internet providers designed to help parents keep their children safe online. Harding has made the issue of child internet safety something of a personal crusade. Before she joined TalkTalk the company had been developing Homesafe, an optional filter to screen out unsavoury content, but she made sure it saw the light of day. As a mother of two girls, now aged seven and eight, she felt the need to act. "These can so easily become polarised issues of moral philosophy, from the free internet rights brigade at one end of the spectrum to the Mary Whitehouse anti-porn brigade at the other, and then no one agrees with anyone on anything and nothing happens. Soon, politicians joined in. At a cyber summit last November, David Cameron urged BT, Sky and Virgin to install filters. By the end of this year, every one of their customers will have a block switched on unless they explicitly opt out. "Internet safety is quite like the road safety issues when I was growing up as a child. You had clunk click advertising and the green cross man coming into schools to talk to children." Harding wants a green cross code for the digital superhighway, including online safety lessons built into the national curriculum in primary schools. Born the Honourable Diana Harding, she is an unlikely technology boss. The granddaughter of field marshall John Harding, who commanded the desert rats in the second world war, she graduated from Oxford and rebelled against an upbringing where she wasn't really expected to have a career. In the early years, she put her five foot two inch frame to good use by moonlighting as a jockey. At the same time, she climbed the corporate ladder, with a stint at McKinsey followed by senior roles at Tesco and then Sainsbury's. Her husband is the Conservative MP and government whip John Penrose, and the prime minister was her contemporary at Oxford. But Harding vehemently denies she used such political connections to advance the child safety agenda. "I promise you I try very hard to stay out of party politics. I run away from it. The right I have had to speak on the subject is because of TalkTalk, not because of anything to do with what my husband does." Harding's second big project is just beginning. Until now, TalkTalk has relied on BT's network to get broadband to its customers. That could be about to change. A pilot joint venture in York will see the firm team up with Sky and fibre-optic specialist CityFibre to connect 200,000 homes. This network will be funded by loans from infrastructure investors, with the future revenue from Sky and TalkTalk customers as collateral. If the project is a success, Harding wants to target all cities with populations between 50,000 and 100,000. Many say this is a threat designed to force BT to lower its charges . "It is not about TalkTalk investing hundreds of millions in digging up roads. We bring customers. That is what enables it to be funded through debt. That's why the share price hasn't tanked, plus the fact that we are, as a company, serially underestimated."

fields.trailText: TalkTalk's Dido Harding has ambitious plans for the internet provider – and for children's safety online

webTitle: US senators say more needs to be done after Credit Suisse conviction

fields.standfirst: Carl Levin and John McCain, who were on committee that led investigation, call charges 'appropriate' but express concerns
fields.body:
The two top US senators who led the investigation into Credit Suisse’s decades-long tax evasion schemes expressed concerns on Tuesday about the Justice Department’s criminal conviction of the bank.

Senators Carl Levin and John McCain welcomed the $2.6bn fine of the bank announced Monday but said more needed to be done. Levin and McCain led the permanent subcommittee on investigations team that uncovered much of the wrongdoing at the bank.

In a statement, Levin said it was “appropriate” that Credit Suisse had been held criminally liable for aiding and abetting tax evasion – the first bank of this scale to held criminally liable for 20 years.

He said the fine struck “an important blow against tax evasion through bank secrecy”.

“But it is a mystery to me why the US government didn’t require as part of the agreement that the bank cough up some of the names of the US clients with secret Swiss bank accounts. More than 20,000 Americans were Credit Suisse account holders in Switzerland, the vast majority of whom never disclosed their accounts as required by US law. This leaves their identities undisclosed, with no accountability for taxes owed. The changes Credit Suisse has agreed to make to its practices are long overdue and welcome, but must be carefully monitored,” he said.

McCain said he was “gratified” by the Justice Department’s decision to require Credit Suisse to plead guilty to criminal wrongdoing. “In such cases, it is vitally important for all Americans to know that no financial institution is ‘too big to prosecute,’” he said. But he added that questions remained.

“Over the next few days, I look forward to reviewing this guilty plea closely to see whether it appropriately holds officers, directors and key executives individually accountable and whether the plea will be sufficient to help deter similar misconduct in the future,” he said.

A number of junior executives at the bank have been prosecuted over the massive tax scam but so far no senior executives have been held accountable. At a press conference on Tuesday, chief executive Brady Dougan, who has been with the bank for 25 years, said he had never considered resigning over the scandal. "Going forward I am very committed to Credit Suisse," he said.

Dougan said the settlement had had little impact on business. “We have found no instances where clients cannot do business with us,” he said. “Our discussions with clients have been very reassuring and we haven’t seen very many issues at all.”

On Monday, attorney general Eric Holder said the scheme had involved “hundreds of Credit Suisse employees, including at the manager level” and said more prosecutions were to come. He said the bank had organised tax dodges for US citizens that ran for decades. “In the case of at least one wholly owned subsidiary, the practice of using sham entities to conceal funds began more than a century ago,” said Holder.

The criminal conviction was, however, carefully constructed in order to protect the bank from severe financial consequences outside of the fine. Nor did it call for the resignation of senior executives. Legal experts said the Justice Department was keen to avoid a punishment that would destroy the bank.

Accounting firm Arthur Andersen was convicted of obstruction of justice in 2002 in relation to its auditing of Enron, the energy firm that imploded in a massive accounting scandal. That ruling was reversed on appeal but was enough to destroy the company.

Nell Minow, board member at corporate governance analyst GMI Ratings, called the criminal convictions “a small step forward”. “This bank is a convicted felon,” she said. “This is a small step forward unless individuals are named and punished. That has to start at the very top.”

John Coffee, Adolf A Berle professor of law at Columbia Law School, said the Justice Department had consulted carefully with the Federal Reserve, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and other regulators to make sure there were “no unanticipated consequences”, resulting from the criminal conviction.

“They were making sure that in a sense this was a red carpet, cushioned landing for Credit Suisse. They don’t want anything like an Arthur Andersen-like debacle,” he said. Coffee said that this case had destroyed the idea that criminal charges would destroy a financial institution and was likely to lead to other criminal charges against other banks now being investigated by the US authorities.

“It is less than a severe sanction when no officers are indicted, when the settlement does not require the dismissal of any employees and where they do not get the names of these US customers,” he said. He said other regulators could take further action, the SEC could bar it from being a money manager, but that was not going to happen.

“Mary Jo White [chair of the SEC] does not want to inconvenience a major bank over a little thing like a federal felony conviction,” he said.

Coffee said the Justice Department wanted the Credit Suisse case to go smoothly so that it could move on to other banks, including US banks, where it has greater jurisdiction. “When they have a US bank, they will have easier jurisdiction over employees,” he said.

• This article was amended on Thursday May 22 to reflect that the senators' concerns relate to the conviction, not an indictment.

webTitle: Vodafone needs time to prove self-help measures are working

fields.standfirst: The operator knows it has underinvested in Europe but spending to fix this will not have an immediate impact
fields.body:
Vodafone's share price, down 5% on Tuesday, stands at its lowest level since the $130bn sale of the 45% stake in Verizon Wireless and the return of the bulk of the proceeds to shareholders. AT&T's decision to spend $49bn buying DirecTV hasn't helped – that deal squashed lingering thoughts that the US group had Vodafone in its sights. But the other reason why a 250p share price in March has become 205p today is that the reinvention of rump Vodafone suddenly looks a long and hard slog.

As if to underline the competitive challenges in continental Europe, Vodafone took a mighty impairment charge of £6.6bn against its assets in Germany, Spain, Portugal, Czech Republic and Romania. Then it said next year's top-line earnings would be £11.4bn-£11.9bn, a few notches below some City expectations.

"Our operational performance has been mixed," says chief executive Vittorio Colao. Unfortunately, it is the operational performance – as opposed to smart deal-making – that matters most in the medium-term.

Vodafone concedes it has underinvested in Europe, thus the mammoth £19bn capital expenditure programme in the next two years to upgrade networks, grab 4G customers and attempt to outmuscle the likes of Deutsche Telekom and Telefonica. But there are few quick gains. The exceptional element of programme – titled Project Spring and comprising £7bn of the £19bn – will have a cash payback period of seven years.

Shareholders are invited to sit back and contemplate the dividend. This year's was hiked 8% to 11p, meaning the dividend yield is a utility-like 5.3%, and Colao's promise is more increases. That commitment looks reasonably solid since he has the leftovers of the Verizon cash to pay for Project Spring. But true credibility requires revenues (down 2% last year) and top-line earnings (down 7%) to start growing again. It may be at least a year before Vodafone can provide hard evidence that its self-help measures are making a difference.
