webTitle: FTSE records biggest daily fall for five weeks on Vodafone and Marks disappointment

fields.bodyText: Leading shares recorded their largest daily fall for more than five weeks after disappointing results from Vodafone and Marks & Spencer. Also on the way down was Tesco, 5.95p lower at 306.05p after analysts at Jefferies moved from buy to hold with a 310p target. They said: With pricing visibly tightening in the UK in the past weeks, we recognise the growing challenges preventing Tesco from turning itself into a mildly growing, strongly cash generative vehicle, as its relative price deficit has recently widened. The rebound in the shares is at odds with accelerating UK margin headwinds, hence our downgrade. Our proprietary pricing confirms an aggressive tightening by Morrisons in recent weeks. On our basket Morrisons is now fully matching Asda, leaving Tesco and Sainsbury some 6% and 7% more expensive respectively. Both will have to work harder to maintain value relevance, justifying our below consensus estimates (4% for the former and 9% for the latter). The implications for our previous bull case are severe enough to warrant a change of heart, in our view. The impact of UK margin pressures on cashflow are meaningful. The triannual pension review may add further to this (we estimate a £260m top-up in 2015/2016), underlining the need for more aggressive action. A Turkish solution could be forthcoming (injecting assets into Migros in exchange for equity?), but with limited benefit to the balance sheet. Realising value from Tesco's more strongly positioned markets remains the obvious option in tackling leverage. Opening new fronts for growth (eg India) or investing where discounter encroachment is absent (UK food online delivery fees) are unwelcome distractions. Meanwhile Morrisons fell 4.5p to 209.5p. Overall the FTSE 100 finished 42.55 points lower at 6802.00, its biggest fall since 11 April, not helped by renewed worries about Ukraine as well as disappointing earnings from US retailers including Home Depot. Of the FTSE 100's fall, just over 12 points came from Vodafone's decline. The mobile phone group slumped 11.85p or 5.4% to 205.3p after the company said its core earnings would fall in 2015 given the need for investment in its business. It took an impairment charge of £6.6bn to cover asset write-downs due to intense competition and regulatory changes in Europe. Its 2014 results showed a 7.4% fall in profits to £12.8bn. Marks & Spencer slipped 5p to 446p as it reported a 3.9% drop in full year profits, the third annual decline in a row. But AstraZeneca recovered from early falls after its rejection of the bid from Pfizer, and closed up 21p at 4308.5p. Carnival cruised the top of the leaderboard, up 78p to £23.80 after Morgan Stanley moved its recommendation from underweight to equalweight, while ITV added 3.8p to 176.6p as Berenberg upgraded from sell to hold with a 180p price target. There was also talk of ITV holding discussions to take a strategic shareholding in Australia's Channel Ten. Elsewhere BT climbed 8.2p to 379.3p after an update from Ofcom, which said it would not set the level of wholesale prices for the company's Openreach fibre service. More signs of the booming housing market - if more signs were needed - came as buy-to-let mortgage lender Paragon reported a 21% rise in underlying pretax profit and made positive noises about the outlook. Its shares closed 33.5p better at 383.6p, the biggest riser in the FTSE 250. But Afren, the oil explorer whose main assets are in Nigeria, ended 8.8p lower at 145.3p after first quarter production of 35,465 barrels a day came in below its forecasts of 40,000 this year. Dragan Trajkov at Oriel Securities said: We see the results on the negative side. Production (although in line with management expectations) is behind 2014 guidance of 40,000 barrels a day. Operating cash flow of around $150m (before working capital, after tax and interest) is fairly low in our view, especially given that includes only $3m of tax and $17m of interest, both of which are set to be significantly more on annualised basis. Finally engineering services group Renew, whose rail division repaired the storm damage to the Great Western Mainline tracks at Dawlish, saw first half revenues jump 48% to £225.8m and profits climb 65% to £7.6m. Its shares fell 4p to 243.5p but Numis raised its target price from 260p to 280p, saying: Good interim results from Renew reflect very strong organic revenue and margin growth across all Engineering Services operations in the first half plus the positive impact of bad weather on Network Rail in the first half (demonstrating the importance of Amco in emergency repair situations). Couple this with benefits from recent acquisitions and the strong cash profile, and we maintain our view that Renew's growth profile remains one of the best in our universe and we accordingly raise our target price to reflect this and maintain a positive recommendation.

webTitle: Vince Cable blasts Glencore Xstrata for lack of women on board

fields.standfirst: Business secretary wants to discuss issue with commodities trader's new chairman, former BP boss Tony Hayward
fields.body:
Vince Cable has attacked commodities trader GlencoreXstrata for failing to break the all-male dominance of its boardroom – now the only one in the FTSE 100 without a woman at the table.

The business secretary said it was "simply not credible" that the company – formed through the controversial merger of Glencore and Xstrata – was unable to find any women with the qualifications to join the board.

He said he would demand a meeting with the firm's new chairman, former BP boss Tony Hayward who was named for the role earlier this month, to hammer the point home, having already discussed the issue with the GlencoreXstrata chief executive Ivan Glasenberg.

"The company has had over three years to address this issue. It has been saying for over a year that they were in the process of appointing a woman to the board, and I specifically met the chief executive to discuss its performance on this issue. It has consistently failed to act," Cable said.

"The vast majority of Britain's top companies have got the message that a diverse top management team is good for business – it is simply not credible that one company cannot find any suitable women."

Cable had earlier appeared on BBC Radio Four's Women's Hour where he described the situation at Glencore as "a bit of a disgrace" and described the changes that had been made in the boardrooms of FTSE 100 companies since Lord Davies set a target in 2011 to get 25% female representation by 2015. At that time, 21 FTSE 100 companies had all-male boards.

Cable made his criticism of Glencore as Hayward chaired the annual meeting of the company in Zug, Switzerland.

It was the second time he had chaired the AGM after being forced to abruptly step up to the task a year ago when the previous chairman Sir John Bond had to step aside after being voted off the board by investors who were furious about the way that the merger with Xstrata had been handled.

Despite speculation that Hayward was on the verge of announcing the appointment of a female director to its board, the new chairman merely said it was "an important ambition to appoint a female director before the end of this year".

Hayward was boss of BP until July 2010 when he was forced out of the oil multinational following a series of PR gaffes in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico. He had caused outrage in the US by saying "I want my life back" in the aftermath of the accident, which killed 11 people and resulted in the worst oil spill in US history.

In echoes of that tragedy, Hayward was forced to tell Glencore investors how 26 of its workers had been killed working for the company in 2013, which his chief executive Ivan Glasenberg summed up by saying: "We did not have a great year".

In an unusually nervous performance, Glasenberg added that "26 fatalities is an area we are working on. It should be noted that we do work in difficult regions. It is important that we get this down to zero". The previous year, 27 staff had died while carrying out their duties.

Hayward had faced questions about his appointment, with some investors hoping an external director would be named for the role amid concerns that Hayward would have little influence over Glasenberg; the chief executive and his four senior lieutenants own around about 20% of the company.

The outcome of the AGM vote showed that 10% of investors failed to back Hayward's reappointment to the board. However, the figure appeared to be kept low by the fact that 33% of Glencore is owned by its own employees.

Excluding the company's staff from the ballot would give a figure of 12% of voting shareholders directly opposing Hayward, while factoring in both abstentions and excluding Glencore staff gives 18% failing to support his reappointment.

webTitle: AstraZeneca shareholder calls on board to reverse Pfizer takeover bid rejection

fields.standfirst: Top 20 investor Schroders criticises rejection but analysts believe it unlikely shareholders can make Anglo-Swedish drugs giant rethink
fields.body:
A major AstraZeneca shareholder has called on the Anglo-Swedish drugs company to reverse its rejection of US rival Pfizer's £69bn takeover.

Schroders, which is one of AstraZeneca's 20 biggest investors, said it was disappointed with the company's "premature" rejection of Pfizer's final £55-a-share offer on Monday morning and called on bosses to "recommence their engagement with Pfizer".

"Schroders notes with disappointment the quick rejection by the AstraZeneca board of the latest offer from Pfizer and the decision of the Pfizer board to draw a premature end to these negotiations by calling their latest proposal final," Sue Noffke, manager of Schroders Prime UK equity fund, said.

"As long-term shareholders, we are strong believers in AstraZeneca and the potential for its innovative growth pipeline, however, given the increase in the offer we would encourage the AstraZeneca management to recommence their engagement with Pfizer, and subsequently their shareholders."

Schroders, which is AstraZeneca's 12th biggest shareholder with a 2% stake, joins other big shareholders AXA Investments and Jupiter Fund Management in publicly criticising AstraZeneca's management. A number of other big investors are also privately expressing anger at the board for rejecting Pfizer's £55-a-share offer without consulting investors.

Under City rules, the only way of resurrecting the deal would be if AstraZeneca's shareholders forced the company's board to reconsider the offer.

Ian Read, the Pfizer chairman and chief executive, has admitted that there is "nothing more we can do".

A source close to Pfizer said the company would be amazed if AstraZeneca's shareholders put enough pressure on the board to force it to reconsider the £55-a-share offer before a Takeover Panel deadline on 26 May. "They would have to make an excruciatingly loud noise," the source said.

The protest would also have to drown out several big investors – including Aberdeen Asset Management, M&G Investments and Woodford Asset Management – that have spoken in support of AstraZeneca's management.

AstraZeneca's shares, which fell 11% following the rejection of the bid on Monday, fell a further 1.25% to £42.34 on Tuesday morning.

webTitle: Royal Mail prompts mixed City views ahead of full year figures

fields.bodyText: Ahead of its first full year results as a listed company, due on Thursday, there seems to be a divergence of opinion on the Royal Mail. On the positive side of the fence is Berenberg's Matthew O'Keeffe, who has just issued a buy note with a price target of 700p. As a reminder the company controversially floated at 330p a share and currently stands at 568p, up 2.5p. Even the most negative commentators have price targets well above October's flotation price. But first the positive. Berenberg said: We forecast 2014 revenue growth of 2.4% to £9.50bn (consensus £9.45bn). Our revenue estimate is based on a 4% year on year decline in UK letter and market mail revenues to £4.60bn, which should be more than offset by a 10.8% year on year increase in parcel revenues to £3.30bn. We forecast that General Logistics Services will increase revenues by 7%, contributing £1.60bn to Royal Mail's top line. Consequently, 2014 will be the first year in which the revenue contribution from parcels will be more significant than revenues from letters. We forecast earnings before interest and tax and before transformation costs of £615m in 2014, some 3% ahead of consensus, which currently stands at £597m. A purely relative valuation supports 700p per share. We have looked at a range of postal peers, including Austrian Post, bpost (Belgium), CTT (Portugal), DP, PostNL (Netherlands), Singapore Post and UK Mail. The most highly-rated stock within this peer group is also the smallest (UK Mail), and the lowest-rated stock is not much bigger (PostNL). We have therefore weighted our postal peer group by market cap... Whether we look at PE, enterprise value/EBITDA or enterprise value/sales, Royal Mail is trading at a relative discount to its peer group, and if we look at dividend yield it is trading at a premium. At 700p, Royal Mail would be trading more like parity. Over at Espirito Santo, Alex Paterson is less keen: Since we initiated coverage on the 5 December, Royal Mail has achieved a positive settlement with the CWU, continued its efficiency programme and reported trading in line with guidance. However, the competitive landscape has intensified significantly, with TNT Post UK rolling out [end-to-end delivery] competition and significant capacity growth, enhanced service and Sunday and evening delivery from other parcel operators. Whilst we think Royal Mail does have scope to raise efficiency and improve its technology, we are increasingly concerned that the rate of decline in letter volumes will become unmanageable, it will be unable to evolve its parcel service offering quickly enough to maintain market share and the market itself will struggle to absorb the level of new capacity. Additionally, we expect the government will try to sell at least some of its 30% stake post results and anticipate this will overhang the stock. We therefore cut our recommendation from buy to neutral, decrease our fair value from 635p to 560p and lower our earnings per share forecasts by 25% and 9% for 2014 and 2015 respectively. And Robin Byde at Cantor Fitzgerald issued a sell note with a 500p target price: We forecast full year revenue of £9.4bn with an operating profit before transformation costs of £680m. The market consensus range for full year operating profit is £617m to £698m, with an average of £668m. This broad range reflects the high operational gearing of the business and uncertainty over core addressed letter volumes, parcel volumes and prices. In late March 2014, Royal Mail announced a further round of job cuts, with a further 1,300 to depart. Total transformation costs for the full year were lifted by £70m to £230m. We expect an update on cost cutting and negotiations with the unions. The dividend payment is a key issue for many investors. Royal Mail has guided to £133m (or 13.3p per share, yield 2.3%) as a final dividend for 2013, payable in July 2014. Market consensus is for a dividend [in 2014] of 21.8p share, a 3.8% yield. We note that historically European parcel companies have offered a 4%-5% yield, in part, to offset the risks to earnings growth from a decline in the core letters business. On the 2014 outlook, we assume Royal Mail will not provide "hard" profit guidance at this stage of the year. We believe that Royal Mail's earnings are likely to come under pressure due to its uncompetitive cost base, declining core letter activity and pricing pressure in parcels.

webTitle: London Stock Exchange and Cobham seek US deals totalling more than $4bn

fields.standfirst: LSE in talks to buy asset managment firm Russell while Cobham snaps up Aeroflex
fields.body:
Pfizer's bid for AstraZeneca may have run into a roadblock but a couple of other multibillion dollar deals - this time UK companies buying US businesses - are in the pipeline.

The London Stock Exchange has confirmed it is in exclusive talks to buy US asset management business Russell Investments from Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance for around $3bn.

LSE's shares have added 8p to £17.72 on the news, but some analysts are not entirely convinced. Numis said:

A deal at that size [$3bn] would be the biggest in the LSE's 213-year history and mark its boldest push into the US where Russell is best known for its equity benchmarks such as the Russell 2000. Given the transformational nature of this deal we have placed the LSE recommendation under review. We do not see the strategic logic of purchasing the asset management business of Russell and would need to be convinced. Should the LSE acquire the index businesses of Russell it would plug the strategic gap in the FTSE portfolio (the US). Should this deal happen price will be key. We believe there will be a trade off between our outlook for price compression, and cross selling FTSE product to Russell customers and Russell product to FTSE customers plus cost synergies.

Meanwhile aerospace and defence company Cobham has agreed to pay $1.46bn for US communications equipment maker Aeroflex. Cobham has slipped 5.7p to 306.5p as it said it would place 65m shares - 6% of its share capital - to help fund the deal. Andy Chambers at Cantor Fitzgerald said:

Cobham is paying 10.5 times current year estimated adjusted EBITDA so valuation is not that stretched in our view, and for an aggregate integration cost of £128m the company expects to achieve synergies of £50m per annum after three years. We estimate half of this would allow the deal to be value creating. Aeroflex is a leading supplier of radio frequency (RF) and microwave integrated circuits and components, and 70% of its sales are to commercial markets. It is therefore aligned with Cobham's strategy, focusing on it strength in RF electronic components but increasing commercial sales.
We continue to regard Cobham as fully valued, and the placing will likely cause some indigestion. However, this does meet many of its strategic acquisition criteria and will be well received by the market to some extent justifying the premium rating against peers. We have been saying for some time that we would like to see the new management team's first self-generated deal and this looks like it, so we will evaluate our position on the stock following completion. Cobham is trading on 14.3 times 2015 consensus earnings per share, and remains a hold with a target price of 280p.

webTitle: UK inflation rate increases to 1.8%

fields.bodyText: The UK rate of inflation rose for the first time in almost a year in April after consumers paid more to travel over the popular Easter period. Annual inflation measured by the consumer prices index rose to 1.8% from 1.6% in March, also pushed higher by petrol prices. It was the first rise in inflation in 10 months, and economists had forecast a smaller increase to 1.7%. The figures from the Office for National Statistics showed that inflation is once again outpacing wage growth, with the latest available data showing average pay rises of 1.7% in the three months to March. The month-on-month figure between February and March showed an increase in earnings of just 1%. Pay had finally caught up with inflation in recent months, following a prolonged period of real wage falls since 2008. The April inflation figure threatens to reignite fears that a cost-of-living crisis is not yet over. The TUC general secretary, Frances O'Grady, said: "Last month we were told the living standards crisis was over. Yet one month later real wages are falling again. Even on a measure that excludes the cost of housing, prices are rising faster than wage packets. "It will be years before workers even recover the earnings they have lost since 2008, let alone start to feel any better off." However, Samuel Tombs, UK economist at Capital Economics described April's rise in inflation as a "blip". He said: "The rise in UK consumer price inflation in April should not be seen as a sign that the economic recovery is causing underlying price pressures to build. "Instead, the increase in CPI inflation from 1.6% to 1.8% in April almost entirely reflects the impact of the later timing of Easter, which fell in April this year but in March last year." The biggest driver of the rise in inflation was higher transport costs as air fares and sea fares increased as people travelled over Easter. Air fares jumped 18% while sea travel costs increased by 22%. Petrol prices also contributed to the higher inflation rate, as unchanged prices in April compared with a fall in the same month last year. The rises were enough to offset a 0.5% fall in food prices. Despite the increase in inflation in April it was the fourth month that the annual rate was below the Bank of England's 2% target. The last period of below target inflation was more than four years ago. "The outlook for inflation over the coming months is benign, with CPI set to stay below the 2% target over the next year," said Sam Hill, senior UK economist at RBC Capital Markets. The Bank of England's latest forecasts published last week suggested inflation will remain close to the 2% target over the next few years. With a lack of inflationary pressure, the bank's governor, Mark Carney, reiterated that the bank would be in no rush to raise interest rates – on hold at 0.5% since March 2009 – with the first rise most likely around the time of the general election in the second quarter of 2015. The Treasury said: "The latest figures show that inflation remains below the target rate and well below half of the peak in September 2011. Lower inflation and rising job numbers show that the government's long-term plan is working and Britain is coming back. The biggest risk to economic security would be abandoning the plan that is creating a brighter economic future."

webTitle: M&S profits dip for third year as retailer fails to reach sales target

fields.standfirst: Chief executive Marc Bolland defends 4% fall in profits to £623m saying group is now in a stronger position after investment programme
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer chief executive Marc Bolland defended his leadership after missing a three-year sales target that he set as a measure of his performance.

M&S reported group sales of £10.3bn for last year – short of the goal of between £10.8bn and £11.4bn Bolland set out two years ago. His original three-year target was for £12.5bn of sales although that figure was revised down.

M&S reported its third year of falling profits, down 4% at £623m – slightly better than analyst forecasts of £615m. Underlying pretax profit was the lowest since 2009, when it was £604.4m.

Sales at UK stores which have been open a year or more barely rose as falling sales of clothing and other general merchandise largely offset the rise in food sales.

M&S shares dropped 3.5% to 435p and were the second-biggest fallers in the FTSE 100 index.

Bolland has been under pressure from shareholders concerned that his £2.3bn investment programme was not paying off. He said the business was now in shape to generate stronger returns after an overhaul of stores, the online operation and internal systems.

Bolland said: "We have been very clear on our strategy. We needed a lot of heavy lifting. This wasn't focused only on profitability. We have said it very clearly over the last few years that there was an intention to make [M&S] more multichannel and international.

"I am happy with what we have done over the last few years. Lots of people would have taken the headwinds and kicked it into the long grass. We have not done that and we are more ready for delivery."

M&S's recovery prospects are tied to the performance of its large clothing business, underklying sales of which have been going backwards for the past three years. However, there was some encouragement for the first time last month when quarterly figures showed an improving trend.

Like-for-like general merchandise sales dropped 1.4% last year. Bolland said the revival in clothing in the final quarter had continued into the current financial year.

M&S said its new M&S.com site would take four to six months to bed in with an impact on clothing and other general merchandise sales in the first quarter of this year.

Bolland has spent the last three years trying to come up with a women's clothing strategy to compete with Next, John Lewis and fashion chains such as Zara. Next's profits overtook M&S's for the first time last year as it reaped the benefits of early investment in online sales.

Bolland, who joined from Morrisons four years ago, said that with his investment plans largely complete the company would start to generate excess cash that would be returned to shareholders. He also predicted improving profit margins in general merchandise from buying more goods directly from Asia.

Finance director Alan Stewart declined to give details on the timing or method of any cash returns, leaving analysts underwhelmed. He said the group's ordinary dividend was important to shareholders but that a special dividend and buying back shares were also options for returning cash to investors.

Tony Shiret, an analyst at Espirito Santo, said: "We found these 2013/14 results disappointing ... We expected firmer indications on capital repatriation, a better general merchandise gross margin recovery than now indicated and we note the comments on online 'settling'."

M&S maintained its full-year dividend at 17p.

Bolland, who joined from Morrisons four years ago, said that with his investment plans largely complete the company would start to generate excess cash that would be returned to shareholders. Finance director Alan Stewart declined to give details on the timing or method of any cash returns, leaving analysts underwhelmed. fields.headline: M&S profits dip for third year as retailer fails to reach sales target
fields.trailText: Chief executive Marc Bolland defends 4% fall in profits to £623m saying group is now in a stronger position after investment programme

webTitle: FTSE falls again as Marks & Spencer and Vodafone disappoint but Carnival cruises higher

fields.standfirst: Leading index falls further from 14 year high on downbeat company news
fields.body:
Disappointing results from two FTSE 100 heavyweights have sent leading shares lower again, but a number of positive broker notes have helped limit the damage.

Carnival has cruised to the top of the leaderboard, up 89p to £23.91 after Morgan Stanley moved its recommendation from underweight to equalweight. However the bank was not entirely positive on the outlook, saying:

[There is a] well rehearsed positive investment case: Carnival's revenue yields are 11% below 2008 levels, industry capacity growth appears low, the newish chief executive is looking to reduce cost ($6bn addressable base, 1% is $0.08 to earnings per share), free cash flow [is] historically a support.
Ultimately, we remain cautious: the industry order book is back to peak, pricing power is weak, cost savings could be reinvested, free cash flow is depressed, and the shares are not that cheap.

Meanwhile ITV has added 2.4p to 175.2p as Berenberg upgraded from sell to hold:

We are upgrading ITV and adjusting our price target from 175p to 180p, reflecting the recent acquisition of Leftfield Entertainment. With the stock having pulled back substantially after the first quarter trading statement, we are more comfortable with the valuation.
The acquisition of Leftfield is surprising given that management had previously stated that it wants to expand in US scripted entertainment, rather than unscripted shows. The deal is earnings per share enhancing, as reflected in our estimate changes, but we caution that the way the deal is being structured means that ITV's earnings per share will reflect substantial growth from Leftfield before it actually has to pay for that. Given the magnitude of earnouts and pension liability, care must be taken in looking at headline PE multiples, in our view.

There was also talk of ITV looking to Australia for its next move. Liberum, which repeated its buy recommendation on the broadcaster, said:

Australian Financial Review reporting that ITV held talks with Australian channel Ten about taking a strategic stake: a bit of an odd one - Ten is probably like Channel 4 in the UK, with more of a focus on reality shows, but it has had its issues. A stake would have not have cost much (current market cap is A$730m (around £400m) and forecast less than A$100m of debt at end of August 2014). Our view is that ITV potentially saw Ten as a testbed for reality formats, which could then be imported into the UK.

Elsewhere BT has climbed 8.8p to 379.9p after an update from Ofcom, which said it would not set the level of wholesale prices for the company's Openreach fibre service.

But overall the FTSE 100 has fallen 31.07 points to 6813.48 ahead of UK inflation figures.

Vodafone is the leading loser, down 8.45p at 208.7p following news that its core earnings would fall in 2015 given the need for investment in its business. It took an impairment charge of £6.6bn to cover asset write-downs due to intense competition and regulatory changes in Europe. Its 2014 results showed a 7.4% fall in profits to £12.8bn.

Meanwhile Marks & Spencer also disappointed, down 13.8p to 437.2p as it reported a 3.9% drop in full year profits, the third annual decline in a row.

AstraZeneca has dropped 84.5p to £42.03 in the wake of an overnight statement from Pfizer confirming it would not raise its final offer except in exceptional circumstances.

webTitle: Pfizer's battle to buy AstraZeneca – timeline

fields.standfirst: AstraZeneca board rejects Pfizer's final £69bn takeover bid, six months after the first approach
fields.body:
25 November 2013

Pfizer chief Ian Read tells AstraZeneca chairman Leif Johansson he would like to discuss a merger. The companies agree to meet early in the new year.

5 January 2014

Pfizer bosses meet AstraZeneca's leadership in New York for "high level" talks. Pfizer proposes paying £58bn, or £46.61 a share, for AstraZeneca. The UK company declines to enter talks and contact ends on 14 January.

26 April 2014

Read contacts Johansson again, asking to restart talks. With no concrete, attractive bid proposal, AstraZeneca's board refuses to discuss a merger.

28 April 2014

Pfizer goes public about its interest in AstraZeneca. The US firm says it is considering an offer in cash and shares at a "significant premium" to AstraZeneca's share price before speculation started. Pfizer says it will move its domicile to the UK to shield its non-US earnings from US taxes.

2 May 2014

Pfizer makes an increased indicative offer of £63bn, or £50 a share. Pfizer writes to David Cameron pledging to base its European operations in the UK and to have 20% of the merged company's research workforce in Cambridge for at least five years. AstraZeneca rejects the increased proposed offer.

4 May

Labour leader Ed Miliband increases political pressure on the bid by accusing the government of "cheerleading" for Pfizer and calling for an independent assessment of whether the proposed takeover is in the national interest.

6 May 2014

AstraZeneca publishes a strategy update highlighting its drugs in development and setting a revenue target of more than $45bn by 2023. Johansson says: "These are benefits that should fully accrue to AstraZeneca's shareholders." Business secretary Vince Cable calls for stronger assurances from Pfizer as part of its bid and says he is prepared to invoke a public interest test.

7 May

With political pressure unrest over potential job losses and cuts to UK science research, Cameron tells MPs he also wants stronger assurances from Pfizer.

8 May

Former science minister Lord Sainsbury calls for Pfizer's approach to be blocked and accuses the US firm of being an asset stripper that wants to "dismember" an important British company.

10 May 2014

In video statements on Pfizer's website, Read says a deal would be a "win-win" for all concerned and praises AstraZeneca's Cambridge research hub along with UK science in general.

13 May 2014

Read and AstraZeneca chief executive Pascal Soriot appear separately at the business, innovation and skills committee. Soriot says a merger could endanger lives by delaying the development of important drugs. Read dismisses the warning as a "red herring" but admits the merger would lead to job cuts and reduced research spending.

14 May 2014

Read and Soriot appear in parliament again, this time before the science and technology committee. Read admits there would be fewer scientists in the combined company than at present but insists Pfizer will honour its commitments to UK investment, which are legally binding. Soriot says research could be set back if his scientists leave the company because they oppose the merger.

15 May 2014

The chair of the science select committee, Andrew Miller, writes to the science minister David Willetts to express his growing concerns about Pfizer's £63bn takeover approach to AstraZeneca, adding to the overwhelming sense of unease within Britain's science community.

16 May 2014

Regulatory filings show Pfizer executives made millions by cashing in their shares in the US pharmaceutical firm, just weeks before renewing a £63bn bid for AstraZeneca.

Ian Read, Pfizer's chief executive and public face of the takeover bid, sold $10.6m in shares on 26 February, according to regulatory filings. Frank D'Amelio , chief financial officer, sold $8.9m of stock on the same day.

16 May 2014

Labour's shadow business secretary, Chuka Umunna, threatens to block the proposed £63bn takeover of AstraZeneca by its US rival Pfizer if the party wins the general election.

18 May 2014

UK government officials begin talks with Brussels over amending the terms of the British government's public interest test, which currently only allows ministers to block takeovers where there are concerns over national security, media plurality or competition.

18 May 2014

New £69.4bn proposal, worth £55 a share, piles pressure on AstraZeneca's board to enter negotiations with Pfizer

19 May 2014

AstraZeneca board rejects Pfizer's final £69bn takeover bid, irking some large shareholders

webTitle: Vince Cable warns booming house prices are destabilising UK economy

fields.standfirst: Business secretary's warning comes as study says mortgage payers risk being trapped in unaffordable deals as rates rise
fields.body:
Vince Cable has warned booming house prices are destabilising the economy and any sane person should worry about what is going to happen when interest rates rise as the economy returns to normal.

The business secretary also warned that household debt in relation to income is set to become significantly higher in the UK than almost anywhere else, and contains serious dangers that represent "a real, real, real worry" for policymakers and homeowners.

He said levels of household debt were forecast to surpass those reached before the financial crash in 2008.

His comments have emerged as a study predicted that one in 10 mortgage payers risk becoming trapped on unaffordable deals as interest rates rise over the next four years.

The research by the Resolution Foundation thinktank found one in four would face financial difficulties after even a modest rate rise, but it particularly highlighted the 770,000 households that were likely to find monthly repayments eating up at least one-third of their disposable income by 2018 at the same time as being unable to switch to better deals to insulate themselves.

In previously unreported remarks at a meeting of the Foundation last week, Cable said the supplementary Help to Buy scheme – designed to help people purchase existing homes as opposed to new-build properties – was simply feeding demand in London and the south-east. He said the deep, underlying problem was not Help to Buy but a failing housing market.

Going further than his previous warnings, the business secretary said: "In the next few years we are going to get back to high levels of household debt in relation to income, significantly higher in the UK than in almost any other country. A lot of this is due to booming house prices. And that contains serious dangers, not least the fact the large numbers of people taking on mortgages at considerably more than three times their income are going to face higher interest rates when we return to normality." He added: "It is a real, real, real worry."

He said: "I am very concerned by the buildup of household debt in relation to income. That was one of the underlying factors in the buildup to the financial crash. It meant mortgage debt was 85% of household debt. People have stopped talking about that. In the last few years the ratio in the UK has fallen back substantially. A lot of people have paid off their debt but the projection is that it is going to start rising rapidly and surpass the previous levels. This is almost entirely a housing story. I have expressed my views forcibly over the last nine months. I do worry about a new surge in house prices with all the practical consequences of that. It is a particular London phenomenon."

At the weekend, Cable said the government needed to listen to warnings from Bank of England governor Mark Carney, who said in an interview on Sunday fast rising house prices were the biggest threat to the economy.

"Any sane person would be worried about it when you have got more than 10% inflation in the market and we have much more than that in London and the south-east," Cable said. "It is important because it is economically destabilising and it contributes enormously to distributional inequalities of wealth."

He added: "If you look at what Help to Buy has done, very little has fed into the London market – the most important was support for purchase of newly built houses. I don't think there is any problem with that … There is a really big, big problem around the housing market but the Help to Buy is one relatively small component of the argument."

The Resolution report, released on Tuesday, said that borrowers had benefitted from record low interest rates and most would be able to ride the tide of gradually rising borrowing costs.

"But for around one-in-four, even modest rate rises could create financial difficulties," said Matthew Whittaker, chief economist at the Foundation and author of the report.

"Those at greatest risk are members of this group who also find themselves unable to access the best deals in the market today. Almost one in 10 households are doubly exposed: facing the prospect of their mortgage becoming increasingly unaffordable in the future and with the market offering them limited, if any, choice today."

"There is still a window of opportunity to think creatively about the best way of reducing the risk to this vulnerable group while we still have ultra-low interest rates. But that era is coming to an end relatively soon and the legacy of easy credit and the associated debt-overhang will have to be reckoned with."

Lowest income households are most likely to be struggling with unaffordable mortgage repayments, according to the research. It found a quarter of those spending more than a third of their income on mortgage repayments are in the bottom tenth of the income distribution. But as interest rates rise, the affordability problem is set to spread up the income distribution, it added. The East of England and London were most exposed to the affordability risk.
